Issue Title: Image Media thumbnail alt text cannot be changed without reuploading the image
Description: Image Media thumbnail alt text cannot be changed without reuploading the image
acr_note: The alt text for image thumbnails in the Media library cannot be edited directly. Users must re-upload the image to modify the alt text, creating a barrier for users who need to correct or update image descriptions.
dev_note: Provide a mechanism to edit the `alt` attribute of image thumbnails within the Media library interface without requiring image re-upload. This could be implemented with an editable text field associated with the thumbnail. Ensure that changes to the `alt` attribute are saved and reflected immediately in the rendered HTML. The `alt` attribute should accurately and concisely describe the image's content and function.
thread_tldr: Users report that alt text for image media thumbnails cannot be updated without re-uploading the image. A patch for Drupal 11 has been provided and tested, but requires further review and testing, specifically regarding tests and a potential integration into an existing test file.
thread_problem: The inability to update alt text for image media thumbnails without re-uploading the image creates an accessibility barrier, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.1.1 (Non-text Content). A patch, drupal_core-3232414-media_image_alt_text_not_updated-34.patch, has been created for Drupal 11 and confirmed to work but still needs further review, specifically regarding tests.

Issue Title: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
Description: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
acr_note: When focus is on the ellipsis ("...") within the pagination, assistive technology users may not receive sufficient context to understand its function (e.g., indicating a jump in page numbers). This can prevent users from efficiently navigating to desired content.
dev_note: Replace the ellipsis ("...") with a `button` or `a` element. Use `aria-label` to provide context about the purpose of the link or button (e.g., `aria-label="View pages 5 through 9"`). Ensure the `aria-label` accurately reflects the range of pages the ellipsis represents. If a button is used, ensure appropriate focus styling is implemented. This approach provides a clear and accessible way for users to understand the pagination structure and navigate effectively.
thread_tldr: The pager template ellipsis ("...") fails accessibility tests. The issue has seen active collaboration and a proposed solution addressing the ellipsis, using aria-label, and test creation but needs rebasing due to core changes.
thread_problem: The pager template's ellipsis ("...") fails accessibility tests due to missing semantic information. The proposed resolution involves adding an `aria-label` to the `<li>` element containing the ellipsis and removing the role="presentation" attribute. A Nightwatch test was created, but the patch needs rebasing due to changes in Drupal core annotations. The issue also raised concerns about WCAG 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) and the appropriateness of using `aria-label` on non-interactive elements.

Issue Title: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
Description: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
acr_note: The CKEditor 5 instance lacks a proper accessible name, potentially hindering screen reader users' ability to identify and understand the purpose of the editor. This could make it difficult to create or edit content.
dev_note: Ensure the CKEditor 5 `<iframe>` element has an accessible name. Use a `<label>` element associated with the editor, or provide an `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attribute on the `<iframe>` element itself if a visible label is not appropriate. Example: `<iframe aria-label="Rich Text Editor">`. The chosen label text should clearly describe the editor's purpose within the context of the page.
thread_tldr: The CKEditor 5 text area was reported to lack an appropriate aria-label for screen readers, leading to accessibility issues. While a fix was attempted, the issue status is now "Needs work," potentially requiring a rebase after bot detected that the patch no longer applies. There are potential solutions offered in the discussion that could avoid fighting with CKEditor over the aria-label.
thread_problem: The CKEditor 5 text area lacks an appropriate aria-label, hindering screen reader users' ability to understand the field's purpose, violating WCAG 2.2 Level AA requirements. The proposed solution involves overwriting the aria-label with the appropriate field label value but this may be a workaround for an upstream bug in CKEditor 5. A patch (comment #31) attempts to place the field label before the aria-label instead of overwriting it.

Issue Title: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation
Description: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation
Taxonomies: Accessibility|Needs Review Queue Initiative|wcag412|Needs change record
acr_note: Submenu buttons in a vertical toolbar may not be properly exposed to assistive technology if they do not follow an established accessibility pattern such as the ARIA disclosure pattern. This can prevent users from understanding the relationship between the button and its associated submenu content and from operating the submenu effectively.
dev_note: Implement the ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in a vertical toolbar to ensure accessibility. If using `<button>` elements, use `aria-expanded` to indicate the visibility state of the submenu and `aria-controls` to associate the button with the submenu's ID. Ensure the button toggles the submenu's visibility and that focus is managed appropriately, including focus return to the button when the submenu closes. Consider using `<details>` and `<summary>` elements if appropriate for your design, as they provide native disclosure semantics. Test with assistive technology to verify correct announcement and keyboard operability. Review the ARIA Authoring Practices Guide (APG) for detailed guidance on the disclosure pattern: https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/disclosure/.
thread_tldr: The issue addresses accessibility concerns related to submenu buttons in the Drupal toolbar, specifically aiming to use the ARIA disclosure pattern with `aria-expanded` for vertical toolbar orientation. The issue is currently marked as "Needs review" after modifications to address concerns about redundancy and compatibility, but requires verification that changes do not adversely affect the `stable9` theme.
thread_problem: The accessibility barrier involves unclear announcement of the submenu button state to screen reader users, addressed by implementing the ARIA disclosure pattern. The current solution involves using `aria-expanded` and visually hidden text for the button label, as well as adding assertions to ensure the accessible name of the button remains consistent when toggled. The latest concern revolves around the potential impact of these changes on themes based on `stable9`, requiring further investigation to ensure backward compatibility. This relates to WCAG 2.2 SC 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) as tagged in comment #14.

Issue Title: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
Description: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
acr_note: The `required` attribute is not valid on the `<fieldset>` element. This may create confusion for assistive technology users who rely on the `required` attribute to understand form requirements.
dev_note: The `required` attribute is not valid for the `<fieldset>` element in HTML. Instead, apply the `required` attribute to the individual `<input>`, `<textarea>`, or `<select>` elements *within* the `<fieldset>`. Ensure sufficient instructions or labels indicate which fields within the fieldset are required. Consider using the `aria-describedby` attribute on the individual required fields to reference instructions if the instructions are visually separated from the form fields.

Issue Title: Cached forms can have duplicate HTML IDs, which disrupts accessible form labels
Description: Cached forms can have duplicate HTML IDs, which disrupts accessible form labels
Taxonomies: Needs backport to D7|Accessibility|Needs framework manager review|Needs frontend framework manager review|Bug Smash Initiative|vpat|wcag412
acr_note: When forms are cached and reused, HTML IDs may become duplicated on a single page. This can break the association between form labels and their corresponding input elements, making it difficult for users, especially those using assistive technology, to understand and interact with the form.
dev_note: Ensure unique HTML `id` attributes across the entire document, especially when dealing with cached or dynamically generated forms. When a label's `for` attribute points to a non-unique `id`, the browser's implicit association is broken. Utilize server-side logic or JavaScript to generate unique IDs for form elements during page load or when caching mechanisms are employed. For example, append a timestamp or unique counter value to the base ID. Verify uniqueness using browser developer tools or accessibility testing tools.
thread_tldr: Cached forms can generate duplicate HTML IDs, violating WCAG 4.1.1 and disrupting accessible form labels, particularly with search forms and AJAX implementations. A patch addressing this by randomizing IDs has been submitted but has introduced regressions; the issue currently needs review and testing.
thread_problem: Duplicate HTML IDs generated in cached forms, specifically affecting form labels and accessibility, cause a WCAG F77 failure of Success Criterion 4.1.1 (Parsing). The proposed solution involves randomizing IDs via `Html::getUniqueId()`, but a patch introduced regressions in contrib modules. Workarounds include modifying templates or cache contexts, but these are not comprehensive solutions. The issue affects Drupal core versions 7, 8, 9, and 10.

Issue Title: Forms with required fields marked by asterisk do not have text explaining what the asterisk means
Description: Forms with required fields marked by asterisk do not have text explaining what the asterisk means
acr_note: Users may not understand that an asterisk indicates a required field, creating confusion about form completion requirements. This can especially impact users with cognitive disabilities or those unfamiliar with the asterisk convention.
dev_note: Provide clear, explicit text near the form to explain the meaning of the asterisk (e.g., "* indicates required fields"). Place this explanation before the first required field in the form. If possible, use the HTML5 `required` attribute on the `<input>`, `<textarea>`, or `<select>` elements. Supplement the visual asterisk with the `aria-label` attribute on the form field to announce "required" to screen reader users (e.g., `<input type="text" required aria-label="Name, required">`). This allows screen reader users to immediately understand which fields are required without having to locate the asterisk explanation. Ensure sufficient color contrast between the asterisk and the background.

Description: High contrast mode needs some more refinement

dev_note: To address this issue, first identify the specific elements or interactions that are not functioning correctly in high contrast mode. Common problems include insufficient contrast between text and background, missing or incorrect border styles, and images that obscure text. Use browser developer tools to inspect the rendered styles when high contrast mode is enabled. Ensure that all text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against its background (3:1 for large text). Use the `forced-colors` CSS media query to detect when high contrast mode is active and apply appropriate styles. Prefer system colors (e.g., `Canvas`, `CanvasText`, `LinkText`) for text, backgrounds, and borders to ensure compatibility with user-defined color schemes. Avoid using fixed color values that may override user preferences. Refer to the Microsoft documentation on supporting high contrast themes in your application: [https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/accessibility/high-contrast](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/accessibility/high-contrast).

Issue Title: Focus does not move to submenu when opened by enter or space key
Description: Focus does not move to submenu when opened by enter or space key
acr_note: When a submenu is opened using the Enter or Space key, focus remains on the parent menu item instead of moving to the first focusable element within the newly opened submenu. This prevents keyboard users from easily navigating into the submenu.
dev_note: When a submenu is triggered by a key press (Enter or Space), script should move focus to the first focusable element within the revealed submenu. Typically, this will be the first `<a>` or `<button>` element within the submenu. Ensure the submenu's display state is properly managed (e.g., using `display: none` and `display: block`, or similar, to avoid focus issues on hidden elements). If ARIA is used, `aria-expanded` should reflect the submenu's visibility. Also, consider using `tabindex="-1"` on the submenu container initially, and removing it when the menu opens, to ensure focus can be programmatically set to the submenu. If the first element should not initially have focus, consider giving the container the focus instead and managing keyboard navigation within the submenu using arrow keys. Refer to established menu implementations in resources like the ARIA Authoring Practices Guide (APG).

A subsequent attempt involved using the `inert` attribute, but this introduced a new issue where the navigation became inoperable at certain screen widths. sandip is currently working on resolving this new issue after removing the `inert` toggle for desktop screens.

Issue Title: Messages should have role=status instead of role=contentinfo
Description: Messages should have role=status instead of role=contentinfo
Taxonomies: Accessibility|aria|Global2020|Bug Smash Initiative|Needs issue summary update|wcag131
acr_note: Using `role="contentinfo"` for messages may not accurately convey their purpose or importance to assistive technology users. `role="contentinfo"` is intended for footer-like content, not dynamic status messages. This can lead to users missing important updates.
dev_note: Use `role="status"` for messages that are important but not necessarily urgent. If a message requires immediate attention, use `role="alert"`. If the message provides suggestions or contextual help, consider `role="tooltip"` or `aria-describedby`. Ensure the message is visually styled to match its semantic meaning. If the message is persistently displayed and contains copyright or legal information, then `role="contentinfo"` might be appropriate within a footer element.
thread_tldr: The issue concerns the incorrect use of `role=contentinfo` for status messages, which violates ARIA landmark rules, and proposes using `role=status` instead for better accessibility. The issue is still active, with a need for review of the latest patch.
thread_problem: The `role=contentinfo` is being incorrectly used for status messages in Drupal, conflicting with the ARIA specification that `contentinfo` should be used for footer-like landmarks. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). The latest attempt to address this involves patches that change the role and adjust the markup, but these have faced challenges with test failures and application to different Drupal versions.

Issue Title: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes
Description: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes
Taxonomies: Blocks-Layouts|Needs Review Queue Initiative|Accessibility|Needs change record
acr_note: When System Menu blocks are placed using Layout Builder, the generated HTML may contain duplicate ID attributes. Duplicate IDs can cause assistive technologies to incorrectly identify page elements, leading to navigation and usability problems.
dev_note: Ensure that all ID attributes generated for System Menu blocks within Layout Builder are unique across the entire page. Use a combination of Layout Builder context and menu item information to generate unique IDs. Consider using a consistent naming convention or a hashing function to avoid collisions. Verify ID uniqueness using HTML validation tools during development and testing. If unique IDs cannot be guaranteed, consider using alternative methods for associating labels and controls, such as ARIA attributes like `aria-labelledby` or `aria-describedby`, but only if semantic HTML solutions are not feasible. Note that `aria-labelledby` requires unique IDs, so consider programmatic generation of IDs for those labels instead of relying on existing potentially duplicated IDs.
thread_tldr: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate HTML ID attributes, impacting accessibility. The issue is currently marked as "Needs work," pending a change record and potential modifications to twig templates, suggesting a need for further refinement and review.
thread_problem: Duplicate HTML ID attributes in System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can create accessibility issues, potentially impacting navigation and landmark identification for users relying on assistive technologies, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.1 (Parsing). The latest proposed solution involves updating twig templates, but this approach requires a change record to alert users who have overridden these templates.
